docs.snippet: A new civilian Government is to take office here Friday amid a growing debate over how it should handle the problem of thousands of citizens who were jailed, disappeared or were forced into exile in the last 12 years of military rule.    Julio Maria...
docs.lead_paragraph: A new civilian Government is to take office here Friday amid a growing debate over how it should handle the problem of thousands of citizens who were jailed, disappeared or were forced into exile in the last 12 years of military rule. Julio Maria Sanguinetti, the 49-year- old centrist who won November's presidential elections, has promised a program of ''national pacification'' to deal with the legacy of the dictatorship and to dismantle the army's repressive apparatus. At the same time, Uruguay's armed forces are not leaving power in disarray. This month the army commander, Lieut. Gen. Hugo Medina, stirred a political storm by warning that ''if we are obliged, we will have no choice but to carry out another coup d'etat.''

headline.main: URUGUAY'S CIVILIAN PRESIDENT TO FACE LEGACY OF ARMY RULE

docs.snippet: The White House today called the latest peace overtures from President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua a ''change without substance'' aimed primarily at influencing votes in the United States Congress.    But Secretary of State George P. Shultz,...
docs.lead_paragraph: The White House today called the latest peace overtures from President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua a ''change without substance'' aimed primarily at influencing votes in the United States Congress. But Secretary of State George P. Shultz, on his way to Latin America, later appeared to leave the door open to a meeting with the Sandinista leader. Adding a third note to the somewhat disjointed Administration response, Vice President Bush renewed President Reagan's call for money to support the rebels seeking the overthrow of the Nicaraguan Government. He said Mr. Ortega's proposals came because the Administration's policy was working.

headline.main: WHITE HOUSE SCORNS PEACE OFFER FROM NICARAGUA

byline.original: By GERALD M. BOYD, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: Nicaragua plans to free a student whose arrest led to a dispute with Costa Rica and caused the cancellation of regional peace talks, a Foreign Ministry official said today.   The student, Jose Manuel Urbina Lara, will be turned over to officials of...
docs.lead_paragraph: Nicaragua plans to free a student whose arrest led to a dispute with Costa Rica and caused the cancellation of regional peace talks, a Foreign Ministry official said today. The student, Jose Manuel Urbina Lara, will be turned over to officials of the Contadora group, who are seeking a regional peace settlement, said Nora Astorga, the Nicaraguan Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs.

headline.main: Nicaraguan Says Sandinistas Will Free a Detained Student

docs.snippet: SATURDAY, MARCH 2, 1985 International       Uruguay's democracy was restored with the inauguration of Julio Maria Sanguinetti as President. His election ended 12 years of military rule. The inauguration also underscored the trend toward democracy...
docs.lead_paragraph: SATURDAY, MARCH 2, 1985 International Uruguay's democracy was restored with the inauguration of Julio Maria Sanguinetti as President. His election ended 12 years of military rule. The inauguration also underscored the trend toward democracy throughout Latin America. Uruguay is the eighth country in the region to pass from military to civilian government since 1979. (Page 1, Column 1.)

docs.snippet: President Reagan said today that the rebels seeking to overthrow the Nicaraguan Government were the ''moral equal of our Founding Fathers.''     In a speech to the annual conference of the Conservative Political Action Conference here, he renewed his...
docs.lead_paragraph: President Reagan said today that the rebels seeking to overthrow the Nicaraguan Government were the ''moral equal of our Founding Fathers.'' In a speech to the annual conference of the Conservative Political Action Conference here, he renewed his call for Congressional approval of $14 million in aid for the rebels. Mr. Reagan also strongly appealed for support of the proposed research program on a space-based defense system against nuclear weapons and said conservative ideology was now the mainstream of American public thought. Speaking about Nicaragua, Mr. Reagan called the rebel forces ''our brothers'' and ''freedom fighters.''

headline.main: REAGAN TERMS NICARAGUAN REBELS 'MORAL EQUAL OF FOUNDING FATHERS'

byline.original: By GERALD M. BOYD, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: Julio Maria Sanguinetti took office as the elected President of Uruguay today, restoring this country's long democratic tradition after 12 years of military rule.     The inauguration also underscored the trend toward democracy throughout Latin...
docs.lead_paragraph: Julio Maria Sanguinetti took office as the elected President of Uruguay today, restoring this country's long democratic tradition after 12 years of military rule. The inauguration also underscored the trend toward democracy throughout Latin America: Uruguay became the eighth country in the region to pass from military to civilian government since 1979. Mr. Sanguinetti, a 49-year-old lawyer with centrist political views, immediately pledged that government by fiat ''will not happen again because all Uruguayans will turn democracy into our great national cause.'' Foreign Dignitaries Present The new President was sworn in before Congress and an array of foreign dignitaries, including the Presidents of Argentina, Bolivia, Colombia, Costa Rica, Guatemala and Nicaragua and the Prime Ministers of Spain and Italy.

byline.original: By ALAN RIDING, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: Secretary of State George P. Shultz and President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua met for an hour here today and appeared to clear the way for a resumption of the Central American peace efforts of the Contadora group.     After the meeting, Mr....
docs.lead_paragraph: Secretary of State George P. Shultz and President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua met for an hour here today and appeared to clear the way for a resumption of the Central American peace efforts of the Contadora group. After the meeting, Mr. Shultz played down the importance of Nicaragua's decision this week to suspend the acquisition of new arms systems and to reduce the number of its Cuban military advisers, saying it ''raises more questions than it answers.'' 'Contadora Process' Stressed ''I don't know that anything much has changed,'' Mr. Shultz continued, ''though perhaps there is the recognition all round that the center of negotiation must be the Contadora process and that the sooner everyone gets back to that process the better.'' The work of the Contadora group, which consists of Mexico, Colombia, Venezuela and Panama, was interrupted earlier this year by a dispute between Costa Rica and Nicaragua over a Nicaraguan youth who was arrested Dec. 24 after taking asylum in the Costa Rican Embassy in Managua.

headline.main: NEW PEACE EFFORT BY LATIN NATIONS BACKED BY SHULTZ

byline.original: By ALAN RIDING, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: MANAGUA, Nicaragua WITH an eye on Congress, where the Reagan Administration is battling for money for the anti- Sandinista rebels, the Nicaraguan Government last week launched a major diplomatic offensive. In a series of declarations - to a...
docs.lead_paragraph: MANAGUA, Nicaragua WITH an eye on Congress, where the Reagan Administration is battling for money for the anti- Sandinista rebels, the Nicaraguan Government last week launched a major diplomatic offensive. In a series of declarations - to a delegation of Roman Catholic bishops headed by Archbishop John J. O'Connor of New York, to foreign diplomats in Managua, and to fellow Latin American heads of state gathered in Montevideo, Uruguay - President Daniel Ortega Saavedra announced a moratorium on purchases of new weapons systems and promised to send home 100 of the Cuban ''military instructors'' who are assisting his army. By offering what he called ''these immediate and unilateral initiatives and decisions,'' Mr. Ortega was going to the heart of the increasingly tense conflict with Washington: the Administration's conviction that in nearly six years in power, the Sandinistas have turned Nicaragua into a beachhead for Soviet and Cuban subversion and a military threat to the rest of Central America. In a move seen by diplomatic analysts as an attempt to pre-empt Administration strategy, Mr. Ortega also proposed to meet with Secretary of State George P. Shultz and he invited Congressional leaders to send a bipartisan committee to come and see Nicaragua's military installations. The Congressmen were welcome to go anywhere they wanted because, he insisted, ''our miitary preparations are totally and purely defensive.''

docs.snippet: The new civilian Government declared a formal end today to censorship that the former military regime had imposed on news dispatches sent abroad. Under military rule, which ended with the inauguration of President Julio Maria Sanguinetti last Friday,...
docs.lead_paragraph: The new civilian Government declared a formal end today to censorship that the former military regime had imposed on news dispatches sent abroad. Under military rule, which ended with the inauguration of President Julio Maria Sanguinetti last Friday, foreign journalists were required to submit copies or recordings of all dispatches to the Interior Ministry before they could be transmitted.

docs.snippet: David A. Hays needed to get away   from New York. So he sailed around the bottom of the world.   With his son, Daniel, Mr. Hays made the passage around Cape Horn in a 25-foot cutter.
docs.lead_paragraph: David A. Hays needed to get away from New York. So he sailed around the bottom of the world. With his son, Daniel, Mr. Hays made the passage around Cape Horn in a 25-foot cutter.
